query: What is Schur Orthogonality and why is it important in the representation theory of compact groups?
response:
Schur Orthogonality refers to a set of orthogonality relations satisfied by the matrix entries of irreducible representations of compact groups. Specifically, for a compact group \( G \), if \( \rho \) and \( \sigma \) are irreducible unitary representations of \( G \), then the matrix elements of \( \rho \) and \( \sigma \) are orthogonal with respect to the Haar measure on \( G \). More precisely, for matrix entries \( \rho_{ij}(g) \) and \( \sigma_{kl}(g) \), the following holds:

\[
\int_G \rho_{ij}(g) \overline{\sigma_{kl}(g)} \, dg = \frac{1}{\dim \rho} \delta_{\rho \sigma} \delta_{ik} \delta_{jl},
\]

where \( dg \) is the normalized Haar measure, and \( \delta \) is the Kronecker delta.

This orthogonality is crucial in the representation theory of compact groups because it allows one to decompose any continuous function on \( G \) into a series of matrix coefficients (via the Peter–Weyl theorem), and to determine the multiplicities of irreducible representations in a given representation. It ensures that irreducible representations are pairwise orthogonal, forming an orthonormal basis in the space of square-integrable functions on \( G \). This makes Schur Orthogonality a foundational tool for harmonic analysis and the classification of representations.

This is crucial as it provides an orthonormal basis for L2(G) in terms of the matrix coefficients of irreducible representations.
